techniques.name: unexpectedAnalogies
techniques.description: Creating comparisons that surprise while clarifying
techniques.example: Like upgrading from economy to business class in the snack world
techniques.best_for: Highlighting significant improvements or quality differences

techniques.name: deliberateUnderstatement
techniques.description: Understating something significant for humorous effect
techniques.example: Battery compartment has all the durability of wet tissue paper
techniques.best_for: Highlighting serious design flaws or limitations

techniques.name: absurdSpecificity
techniques.example: Perfect for photographers whose flashes consume batteries like a toddler with Halloween candy
techniques.best_for: Creating vivid user scenarios that readers can identify with

techniques.name: selfDeprecatingObservations
techniques.description: Using personal shortcomings to highlight product features
techniques.example: We've become popcorn snobs, vacuum-sealing kernels for optimal freshness

techniques.name: creativeTerminology
techniques.description: Inventing colorful terms for standard features or issues
techniques.example: Artery-assassin oils instead of unhealthy oils
techniques.best_for: Making technical terms more memorable and engaging

figurative_language_implementation.description: Guidelines for implementing effective figurative language in reviews

examples.strength: Combines humor with clear visual understanding

examples.analogy: Velcro that could probably hold a small aircraft together

vivid_imagery.description: Use absurd but crystal-clear comparisons that create immediate mental pictures

categories.name: physicalStateComparisons
examples: feeling like you walked out of a spa vs. just crawled out of a losing boxing match
walking popsicle for abnormally low temperature reading
internal organs hosting their own Summer Olympics for fever symptoms
categories.application: Perfect for contrasting expected vs. actual experiences

categories.name: designContradictionAnalogies
examples: steering wheel on a toaster for features that contradict product purpose
handle on a door that doesn't open for misleading design elements
wheels on a chair that's bolted to the floor for unused potential
categories.application: Highlights illogical design choices or misleading features

categories.name: effortDifficultyAnalogies
examples: moving to the bathroom mirror would be like running a marathon for simple tasks made difficult
energy of a sloth on sedatives for depleted state affecting product use
playing temperature bingo for inconsistent results
categories.application: Illustrates how product complexity affects real-world usage

principles: Create immediate visual understanding through extreme but relatable images
Use absurdity to highlight product shortcomings without sounding bitter
Pair opposing images to create contrast that illustrates points
Connect analogies to specific product features or experiences

natural_humor_techniques.description: Strategies for integrating humor naturally within product descriptions rather than as standalone jokes
principles: Embed humor directly within functional descriptions
Use figurative language that both entertains and informs
Allow product characteristics to dictate humor style

embedded_metaphors.description: Using metaphors that are directly integrated into product descriptions

examples.weak: The basin is very sturdy. It can hold a lot of water without wobbling.
examples.strong: The basin can be relocated when full with only the slightest tsunami effect.

descriptive_hyperbole.description: Using measured exaggeration to highlight product qualities

examples.weak: The handles are thin and can be uncomfortable when carrying a full basin.
examples.strong: The cut-out handles are thinner than our patience at 4AM when lifting a water-filled basin.

functional_similes.description: Creating comparisons that directly illustrate product functionality

examples.weak: The collapsibility feature wasn't useful for our large sink.
examples.strong: The collapsibility feature is as useful to us as sunglasses at midnight.

implementation: Look for opportunities to transform plain descriptions into vivid imagery
Connect humor directly to the specific functionality being described
Use figurative language that creates immediate visual understanding
Balance hyperbole with accuracy - exaggerate for effect without misleading

implementation_sequence: Identify key product features that would benefit from figurative enhancement
Select appropriate figurative technique based on feature characteristics
Add figurative element after core information
Verify figurative language enhances rather than obscures information

strategic_placement.creative_elements: Strong thematic establishment, sensory hooks, emotional context
strategic_placement.purpose: Engage reader and establish review personality

strategic_placement.creative_elements: Limited, strategic figurative language, minimal thematic elements
Micro-narratives, sensory details, moderate thematic presence
Strategic analogies, measured personality in select list items
strategic_placement.purpose: Enhance memorability of key points while maintaining clarity
Create satisfying closure and reinforce key messages

conversation_element_integration.description: Methods for creating a conversational tone without sacrificing information quality

techniques.name: strategicInformality
techniques.description: Using selective informal language to create connection

examples.weak: This device performs satisfactorily on most surfaces.
examples.strong: This thing works like a charm on pretty much any surface you throw at it.

techniques.implementation: Use informal wording primarily in experiential sections while maintaining precision in technical sections

techniques.name: directAddress
techniques.description: Addressing the reader directly in select situations

examples.weak: It is recommended to charge the device fully before first use.
examples.strong: Do yourself a favor and charge this fully before your first use.

techniques.implementation: Use primarily in practical advice sections to create immediacy

techniques.name: rhetoricalQuestions
techniques.description: Using strategic questions that reader would likely ask

examples.weak: Many people wonder about battery life.
examples.strong: But what about battery life? That's where things get interesting.

techniques.implementation: Use to transition between sections or introduce new evaluation criteria

balance_guidelines: Conversational elements should comprise 15-20% of personality content
Use conversational tone primarily in opening and experiential sections
Reduce conversational elements in technical specifications
Maintain clear factual content even when tone is conversational

product_category_adaptations.description: Adapting personality techniques for specific product categories

adaptations.voice_guidance: Knowledgeable but not elitist; passionate but practical
specialty_approaches: Compare with outdated technology for contrast
Reference tech frustrations readers will recognize
Use tech-adjacent metaphors from other domains
Use cooking metaphors for non-cooking products

adaptations.voice_guidance: Thoughtful, measured, balanced between science and experience
specialty_approaches: Use gentle humor that acknowledges insecurities
Maintain respectful tone regarding body concerns

implementation_guidance: Consider product purpose and target audience when selecting techniques
Adjust personality level based on product category sensitivity
Maintain authentic voice regardless of product category

authenticity_enhancement.description: Techniques for ensuring personality feels genuine rather than manufactured

techniques.name: specificityAnchoring
techniques.description: Tying personality elements to highly specific details

examples.generic: The lamp has a nice glow.
examples.authentic: The lamp creates that perfect golden-hour glow that makes even our 20-year-old couch look Instagram-worthy.

techniques.implementation: Include precise, unusual details that would be difficult to invent

techniques.name: quirkyObservation
techniques.description: Noting unexpected or seemingly trivial discoveries

examples.authentic: Oddly enough, the power button makes a different sound depending on whether you're turning it on or off - a small detail I unexpectedly appreciate.

techniques.implementation: Include observations that serve no marketing purpose but feel real

techniques.name: contextualAnecdotes
techniques.description: Brief stories that provide authentic usage context

examples.authentic: During our red-eye to Boston, I managed to use this without waking my seat neighbor - something my previous model never accomplished.

techniques.implementation: Include specific circumstances, locations, or people (without identifying details)

verification_questions: Does this sound like something a real person would notice?
Would marketing copy ever include this observation?
Does this reveal something unexpected about the product?
Is this observation specific enough that it would be difficult to apply to similar products?
